repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Consolidation Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is unsatisfactory; Project sustainability is likely;
            institutional development impact is modest; Bank performance
            is satisfactory; and Borrower performance is unsatisfactory.
            Among the lessons cited from this project were the
            following: Given that the key focus of the package was the
            reform of the energy sector involving operational efficiency
            improvements, cost recovery, sector unbundling and creation
            of market structures and independent regulation conducive to
            private investment and actual privatization of the
            distribution segment, the choice of structural adjustment
            lending as the Bank instrument could be regarded, in hind
            sight, as inappropriate. As years passed and as the economy
            improved, the need for reform assistance became less urgent
            and the government tended to become lukewarm towards the
            more difficult parts of the reform program. Towards the end
            of 2004, four years after approval of the credit, it
            appeared as though the government was not keen to draw down
            the third tranche. This experience would appear to indicate
            that adjustment loans are best limited to one or two
            tranches and a period not exceeding 12 to 18 months. The
            reform program was ambitious in relation to the envisaged
            time frame and the implementation capacity of the government
            agencies. Shifting political landscapes added to the
            problem. Another lesson is the obvious merit of back loading
            the disbursement. It is fair to conclude that a reasonable
            amount of reform was achieved for the amount of money that
            was disbursed under the first two tranches. The toughest
            conditions were attached to the third tranche, which also
            had the largest share of the total credit. The operation
            also seems to highlight the need for proper sequencing of
            reform. In countries with a high degree of nonpayment and
            non-cash payments, sector unbundling actually exacerbates
            the problem and creates intra industry arrears starving the
            upstream activities of any cash. A measure of control over
            nonpayment problem has to be achieved through such steps as
            effective legislation against theft of power, dismissal of
            erring employees, disciplined disconnection of supplies to
            non-payers, prohibition of non-cash settlement of any kind,
            institution of effective and speedy bankruptcy procedures
            against large defaulting consumers, restructuring of the
            arrears and rescheduling of debts and writing off
            irrecoverable arrears, before undertaking sector unbundling.

Kyrgyz Republic - Consolidation Structural

repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Consolidation Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the objectives of the reform
            program, the Consolidation Structural Adjustment Credit in
            the Kyrgyz Republic, will improve the fiscal, and business
            environment, and ensure a minimum acceptable level of
            access, and standards of utility services, particularly to
            the poorest groups. The project will: 1) implement tax
            reforms, while improving revenue mobilization; 2) reduce
            regulatory barriers at entry, and operation of businesses,
            and enhance competitiveness; 3) improve the financial
            condition of utilities, initiating a privatization process;
            and, 4) strengthen the social protection system, partly to
            compensate the poor for utility tariff increases. It is
            expected that the project will consolidate fiscal
            adjustment, and improve private sector growth, fostering
            reforms in the energy sector, while minimizing its social
            costs. However, risks exist, particularly on the political
            front associated with the social aspects related to the
            impact of tariff increases, which may dissipate due to
            sociopolitical pressures. Investor interest in the
            privatization process are further risks to consider, as well
            as the ambitious reform program, which will require a strong
            institutional capacity for its implementation. Nonetheless,
            it is considered that the benefits of the operation, far
            outnumber the potential risks.
